You guys have it real easy. I never had it like this where I grew up. But I send my kids here. Because  the fact is, whether you ceserve it or not: you go to one of the best schools in this country. Max's eyes light-up.

Now for some of you it doesn't matter. You were born rich and you're going to stay rich. But here's my advice to the rest of you: take dead aim on the rich boys. Get them in the crosshairs. That's right. A little one act. And my mother read it and felt I should go to Rushmore. And you read it and you gave me a scholarship, didn't you? Dr. Guggenheim nods.

Couldn't we just let me float by? For old times’ sake?
(grimly) Can't do it, Max.
Max and Dirk come out the door into the cold. They head across the grass.

(concerned) Oh, no. Not again. What are you going to do?
The only thing I can do. Try to pull some strings with the admin- istration, I guess.

At least I saved Dirk from the horror.  Max turns the page of his book, There is a little note written in the margin in pencil with an arrow pointing to text. Max frowns. He turns the book sideways to read it.

which reminds me of a quote from Henry James: Try to be one of the people on whom nothing is lost. I Max's frown disappears. A change comes over his face. His eyes glaze over dreamily. He looks to Alex.

{pause) I don't know. I think you just got to find something you love to do, then do it for the rest of your life. (shrugs) For me, it's going to Rushmore. Max looks very serious. Mr. Blume smiles and nods.
